question: During a class discussion about a story, what should you do if you want to respond while someone else is still talking?

answer_options.A: Start talking at the same time so your idea is heard quickly.
answer_options.B: Listen quietly until the speaker finishes, then raise your hand to share your thought.
answer_options.C: Whisper your response to the student next to you instead of waiting.
answer_options.D: Interrupt and ask a question about what the speaker just said.

answer_explanation: Listening first and waiting until the speaker is finished shows respect for others and follows the rule of speaking only when it is your turn.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in SL.3.1.B at hard difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question: During a class discussion about reading goals, Mr. Kim reminds the students of three rules: (1) raise your hand and wait to be called on, (2) listen carefully to one speaker at a time, and (3) stay on the topic of the day. Which student’s action BEST follow all three rules?

answer_options.A: Maya blurts out her opinion while another student is still talking.
answer_options.B: Ben raises his hand, waits to be called on, and then says, "I agree with Maya’s idea about reading more magazines. Another way is to pick a book from our library that we can share with the class."
answer_options.C: Carlos raises his hand, is called on, and then tells a long story about his weekend that does not mention the discussion topic at all.
answer_options.D: Jenny whispers her ideas to a neighbor during the discussion so she can talk more quickly without waiting.

answer_explanation: Ben waits his turn, restates Maya’s point (showing he listened), and then adds a related idea about reading goals, so he follows every part of the class rule.
subject: ELA

question: During a class discussion about insects, your friend says, "A beetle’s hard wings protect it from predators." Which question should you ask next to check your understanding of what your friend said?

answer_options.A: "What is your favorite insect?"
answer_options.B: "How does a beetle’s hard wing protect it from predators?"
answer_options.D: "I once saw a beetle in the garden."

answer_explanation: Option B restates the friend’s idea and asks a clarifying question about the protection the hard wings provide, so it best shows you are checking your understanding of what was said.
subject: ELA

question: During a class discussion about making a class pet care schedule, the teacher says, "The hamster needs fresh water every school day, and on weekends one student must visit the classroom to feed it." Which student response BEST shows asking a question to check understanding of the information presented and links to the teacher’s remark?

answer_options.A: “I can help draw the schedule after lunch.”
answer_options.B: “You said the hamster needs water every school day and a visitor on weekends—will each day have one student signed up to take care of it?”
answer_options.C: “Do you think the hamster might like cheese for breakfast?”
answer_options.D: “We could put the schedule chart near the window for everyone to see.”

answer_explanation: Option B repeats the key details (water every school day, someone feeds on weekends) and asks a clarifying question about how many students will be signed up, so it checks understanding and stays connected to the teacher’s point. The other options either give a new idea without checking understanding (A, D) or ask a question that does not include the important details from the teacher’s remark (C).
subject: ELA

question: During a class discussion about volcanoes, your classmate says, "I read that lava can be over 1,000 degrees Celsius when it erupts." Which response BEST shows that you are asking a question to check understanding, staying on topic, and linking your comment to your classmate's remark?

answer_options.A: You said lava is over 1,000 degrees—will it hurt the ground near the volcano?
answer_options.B: Scientists also study icebergs that float in the ocean.
answer_options.C: How many degrees is the classroom heater?
answer_options.D: Volcanoes are awesome and really loud!

answer_explanation: Option A asks a specific question about the heat of the lava, directly references the classmate's statement, and remains on the topic of the eruption. The other options either shift the topic, do not ask a clarifying question, or fail to connect to the remark.
subject: ELA

question: After a class discussion about caring for class pets, Raj says: "I used to think feeding the hamster was the only job, but now I know cleaning the cage and checking the water are just as important." Which choice shows Raj explaining his own ideas in light of the discussion?

answer_options.A: Feeding the hamster is my favorite job in the class.
answer_options.B: I used to think feeding the hamster was the only job, but now I see that cleaning the cage and checking the water matter too.
answer_options.C: The hamster looks cute when it runs on the wheel.
answer_options.D: I still believe feeding the hamster is the most important job.

answer_explanation: Option B shows Raj describing how his understanding changed after the discussion and what he now realizes, demonstrating the skill of explaining his own ideas in light of the discussion.
subject: ELA

question:
During a class discussion about how a community garden can help the school, classmates share these ideas:
• Jordan: "The garden will teach us how plants grow."
• Sofia: "We can sell vegetables at the school market and raise money for clubs."
• Kai: "But we need to water the plants every day, or they will dry out."

Earlier, you thought, "The garden is a waste of time because nobody will use it." After listening to Jordan, Sofia, and Kai, which response best explains your own idea in light of the discussion?

answer_options.A: I still believe the garden is a waste of time because nobody uses it, so we should tear it up instead.
answer_options.B: I realize the garden could teach us about plants and raise money, and if enough students help with watering, it might work for the school.
answer_options.C: We would need to water the plants every day anyway, so that is the only thing I agree with from the discussion.
answer_options.D: I agree with Jordan and Sofia, so the garden is definitely a good idea even if we do not have many students.

answer_explanation: Option B shows the speaker revising the original idea by connecting it to all three classmates’ points—learning about plants, earning money, and taking care of the garden—while still stating a new reason (not having enough students). It demonstrates how the discussion changed and expanded the speaker’s thinking. The other choices either ignore the classmates’ ideas (A, C) or give only a vague agreement without explaining a revised understanding (D).
subject: ELA

question: After a small-group discussion about ways to reduce food waste, which response best shows a student explaining their own idea while also demonstrating they understood what others said?

answer_options.A: We should all try to waste less food at home.
answer_options.B: Jaden said we could feed leftover fruit to the cafeteria animals, so I think we should start a fruit-bin program right away.
answer_options.C: I’m not sure anyone can do anything about food waste.
answer_options.D: Jaden mentioned leftover fruit and I like fruit.

answer_explanation: Option B references Jaden’s idea about leftover fruit and adds a new personal suggestion (a fruit-bin program), so it explains the speaker’s understanding of the discussion and a fresh idea.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in SL.3.2 at easy difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question:
Your class listens to this announcement:

“Every Monday through Wednesday, our cafeteria serves a ‘Meatless Meal’—a big pot of vegetarian chili made with beans, corn, and tomatoes. Ms. Gomez says that so far this month, we have saved 20 pounds of ground beef. That means 20 fewer cows needing food and water, and 20 fewer plastic trays in the trash. Last week, 75 students tried the chili and said they would choose it again. The cafeteria is planning to add another Meatless Meal on Friday.”

Then you see this bar graph on the screen:

Beef Saved (pounds) | January – not Meatless | 0
                  | February – 3-day Meatless | 20
                  | March – planned 5-day Meatless | 40

Which choice BEST states the MAIN IDEA and gives TWO supporting details—one from the announcement and one from the graph?

answer_options.A: Main idea: The cafeteria’s Meatless Meals are helping the class use less beef. Spoken detail: The announcement said 20 pounds of ground beef have been saved this month. Graph detail: The bar for February (Meatless 3 days) is at 20 pounds, while January (no Meatless days) is at 0.
answer_options.B: Main idea: Students do not like the vegetarian chili at all. Spoken detail: The announcement said only 75 students tried the chili, and graph detail: The bar for March shows 40 pounds of beef saved, not 0.
answer_options.C: Main idea: The cafeteria will stop serving Meatless Meals after February. Spoken detail: The announcement said the cafeteria is adding another Meatless day on Friday, and graph detail: The bar for January shows 0 pounds saved.
answer_options.D: Main idea: Eating more beans and corn is the most important goal. Spoken detail: The announcement said the chili is vegetarian, and graph detail: The bar for February shows 20 pounds saved.

answer_explanation: The main idea is that the Meatless Meals are reducing beef use in the cafeteria. This is supported by the spoken detail that 20 pounds of beef have been saved this month, and the graph shows the bar rising from 0 in January to 20 in February, matching the claim.
subject: ELA

question:
During a morning science lesson, your teacher read the paragraph below aloud:

"Bees are important pollinators. They buzz from flower to flower collecting nectar. As they do, pollen sticks to their bodies and is carried to the next bloom. Without bees, many plants would not be able to make seeds or fruit."

Which sentence best states the main idea of the paragraph?

answer_options.A: Bees buzz from flower to flower collecting nectar.
answer_options.B: Pollen sticks to bees’ bodies and is carried to other flowers.
answer_options.C: Many plants would not be able to make seeds or fruit without bees.
answer_options.D: Bees play a central role in helping plants grow through pollination.

answer_explanation: The paragraph gives several facts about how bees move between flowers and transfer pollen, all of which support the central point that bees are important pollinators. Option D restates this central idea, while the other choices list individual details rather than the overall message.
subject: ELA

question: During a class report, your friend says, "I learned that cheetahs are the fastest land animals and can run up to 70 miles per hour." Which question would be the BEST example of asking for more detail about what the speaker shared?

answer_options.A: Do you like cheetahs?
answer_options.B: What kinds of prey do cheetahs chase when they run so fast?
answer_options.D: Is 70 miles per hour faster than a car?

answer_explanation: Option B asks about the prey cheetahs chase, which is related to the speed the speaker mentioned, and invites the speaker to give more specific information, showing appropriate elaboration.
subject: ELA

question: A speaker says, "When a volcano erupts, magma rises through cracks in the Earth's crust, and ash clouds can block sunlight for miles around." Which question would best help the class understand more about what the speaker just said?

answer_options.A: What color is the magma when it reaches the surface?
answer_options.B: How does ash make the air feel during an eruption?
answer_options.C: Why does the magma rising cause the ash clouds to form above the volcano?
answer_options.D: Have volcanoes erupted more often in recent years?

answer_explanation: Option C connects directly to both main ideas in the speaker’s statement—the movement of magma and the formation of ash clouds—and asks for a cause-and-effect explanation that would encourage the speaker to elaborate. The other options either shift focus to unrelated details (A, D) or ask about only one part of what was said (B).
subject: ELA

question: A classmate says, “I visited my grandparents’ farm last weekend. We helped feed the animals, and the horses were very friendly.” Which follow-up question would BEST help you learn more about what the speaker did on the farm?

answer_options.A: Did you have fun on the farm?
answer_options.B: What else did you do on the farm besides feeding the animals?
answer_options.C: How many horses did you see?
answer_options.D: Was the drive to your grandparents’ house long?

answer_explanation: Option B invites the speaker to add more details about their activities beyond what was first mentioned, showing an appropriate follow-up that deepens the conversation.
subject: ELA

question: Jada is choosing a fact to include in her class report about the water cycle. Which fact would BEST help her report meet the standard for using appropriate facts and relevant details?

answer_options.A: Water evaporates from oceans, rises as vapor, and later falls back to Earth as rain or snow.
answer_options.B: The water cycle is an interesting topic that students study in science class.
answer_options.C: You can drink water from a faucet, and it tastes good with a slice of lemon.
answer_options.D: My brother learned about the water cycle last year, and he says it was fun.

answer_explanation: Option A gives a clear, accurate fact that directly relates to the water cycle and includes descriptive details about how it works, helping the report meet the standard. The other options are either too general, off-topic, or not useful facts for the report.
subject: ELA

question: A student is preparing a report about rainforests. Which plan BEST shows that the student understands how to include appropriate facts, relevant descriptive details, and speak at an understandable pace?

answer_options.A: Adds many interesting rainforest facts but speaks so quickly that listeners cannot follow.
answer_options.B: Focuses on vivid descriptions of colorful parrots and sparkling waterfalls but includes no factual information about the rainforest.
answer_options.C: Adds two accurate facts about canopy height and rainfall, describes how monkeys dart between green leaves and how thick vines twist down, and practices speaking slowly enough for the audience to follow.
answer_options.D: Includes accurate facts about rainfall and canopy height and speaks at a clear pace, but adds long, unrelated stories about a vacation to the Galápagos Islands.

answer_explanation: Option C includes two accurate facts (canopy height and rainfall), vivid, on-topic descriptive details (monkeys darting, thick vines), and a clear pacing cue (speaking slowly so listeners can follow). Each other option leaves out at least one required element: A lacks pacing, B lacks facts, and D lacks relevance.
subject: ELA

question: Mr. Lopez asked the class to share a brief report about their favorite animal. Which student’s report BEST follows the speaking and listening standard by including appropriate facts, relevant descriptive details, and clear pacing?

answer_options.A: Student A speaks quickly without pauses: "Pandas eat bamboo and live in China. That’s all."
answer_options.B: Student B whispers softly so the class cannot hear and says: "Pandas . . . are . . . you know . . . from . . . nature videos."
answer_options.C: Student C says in a clear voice: "Giant pandas have black-and-white fur that helps them blend into the bamboo forests of China. Because they eat bamboo almost all day, they rarely leave their hiding spots among the tall stalks."
answer_options.D: Student D stands straight and says: "I like pandas because they are cute. They are in zoos and people like to watch them."

answer_explanation: Student C’s report gives clear facts (pandas eat bamboo almost all day), vivid, relevant details (giant panda, black-and-white fur, gentle giant), and is phrased in complete sentences with pauses that make it easy to follow, meeting the standard in every way. The other reports are missing at least one required element.
subject: ELA

question: Which action best shows a third-grader meeting the goal of creating an engaging audio recording of a story or poem?

answer_options.A: Read the story very fast without any pauses or expressions.
answer_options.B: Read the story smoothly at a steady pace and include labeled pictures that match important details.
answer_options.C: Read the story in a flat, quiet voice and skip difficult words instead of trying them.
answer_options.D: Add many bright pictures but whisper the words so no one can hear the story.

answer_explanation: Option B demonstrates fluid reading at an understandable pace and adds visual displays that highlight key details, which is exactly what the standard requires.
subject: ELA

question: Jamal’s group created an audio recording of a folktale for the school website. When they played the draft, the reading sounded uneven—some words were rushed and others were slowed—and there were no pictures to help listeners follow the action. Which revision would BEST help the project meet the expectations of standard SL.3.5?

answer_options.A: Keep the original reading but add a colorful picture after every sentence to make the recording look exciting.
answer_options.B: Lower the volume of the recording slightly and add background music, but do not change the reading or include any visuals.
answer_options.C: Practice reading the story smoothly with expression, record it again at a steady pace, and insert a few clear illustrations that match the main events of the tale.
answer_options.D: Replace the narrator’s voice with a computer voice that never changes tone and show a fast-moving slideshow of unrelated photographs.

answer_explanation: Option C corrects the uneven pacing by re-recording with fluent, steady reading and adds visuals that support key events, addressing both parts of SL.3.5. The other options either ignore pacing, use visuals that don’t support the text, or introduce new problems.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in SL.3.5 at medium difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question: Your teacher asks, “Why did you choose that book?” Which response is a complete sentence that gives the requested detail?

answer_options.A: I chose this book because it has pictures of animals.
answer_options.B: Because it has pictures of animals.
answer_options.C: This book with pictures of animals.

answer_explanation: Option A has a subject (I) and a verb (chose) and clearly explains the reason, making it a complete sentence with the requested detail.
subject: ELA

question: During a science experiment, your teacher asks, "Why did your group stir the sugar water, and how did it help the sugar dissolve faster?" Which response best follows the standard of speaking in complete sentences to provide the requested detail and clarification?

answer_options.A: We stirred the sugar water because stirring moves the water around, so the sugar particles could escape and dissolve more quickly.
answer_options.B: Because it helps the sugar dissolve and stuff.
answer_options.C: We stirred it; the sugar dissolved fast.

answer_explanation: Option A is a single, complete sentence that answers both parts of the teacher’s question—why the group stirred the water and how stirring helped the sugar dissolve—using clear, specific details. The other options are either sentence fragments, lack the requested explanation, or do not include measurable clarification.
subject: ELA

question: During a class discussion, your teacher asks, "What did you learn from the science experiment?" Which response best follows the standard by using a complete sentence and giving enough detail?

answer_options.A: Because it’s cool.
answer_options.B: We learned that mixing baking soda and vinegar creates carbon dioxide bubbles.

answer_explanation: Option B is a complete sentence that begins with the subject "We" and includes the detail "that mixing baking soda and vinegar creates carbon dioxide bubbles." The other options are fragments or lack the requested clarification.
subject: ELA

question: Which sentence best introduces the topic, clearly states an opinion, and lists reasons for that opinion?

answer_options.A: Schools should let students play outside every day because it is fun and gives us energy for class.
answer_options.B: I think schools should let us play outside every day, like how we jump rope and run.
answer_options.C: Schools let students play outside sometimes.
answer_options.D: Playing outside is fun, and sometimes we jump rope.

answer_explanation: Sentence A names the topic (schools and playing outside), gives an opinion (schools should let students play every day), and lists two reasons (fun and energy for class).
subject: ELA

question:
Read the four opening paragraphs for an opinion piece about field trips. Which paragraph BEST introduces the topic, clearly states the writer’s opinion, and sets up an organizational structure that lists reasons?

A. Field trips happen at school. Students ride a bus to interesting places. Teachers plan the trips carefully.

B. Field trips should be a regular part of our school schedule. First, they help us learn by doing. Next, they give us a break from sitting in class. Finally, they let us visit places we might never see.

C. I really like field trips because they are fun. The bus ride is exciting, and sometimes there are surprises.

D. Some people think field trips are unnecessary, but many students enjoy them very much. Trips can be planned in different ways depending on the weather.

answer_options.A: Field trips happen at school. Students ride a bus to interesting places. Teachers plan the trips carefully.
answer_options.B: Field trips should be a regular part of our school schedule. First, they help us learn by doing. Next, they give us a break from sitting in class. Finally, they let us visit places we might never see.
answer_options.C: I really like field trips because they are fun. The bus ride is exciting, and sometimes there are surprises.
answer_options.D: Some people think field trips are unnecessary, but many students enjoy them very much. Trips can be planned in different ways depending on the weather.

answer_explanation: Paragraph B names the topic (field trips), states a clear opinion (they should be a regular part of school), and previews three reasons using an ordered structure (First, Next, Finally). The other choices are missing at least one required element: A lacks an opinion, C lacks an organized list of reasons, and D lacks a clear opinion.
subject: ELA

question: A student is writing an opinion piece about having a class garden. Which introduction best introduces the topic, clearly states an opinion, and sets up reasons that will follow?

answer_options.A: A class garden could be fun. Some students like digging in the dirt, and bees might visit the flowers.
answer_options.B: I think our class should start a garden because it teaches science, gives us healthy snacks, and lets us work together.
answer_options.C: Gardens have plants, shovels, and watering cans. Have you ever seen a seed sprout?
answer_options.D: I love tomatoes! Last summer I planted a seed in my backyard.

answer_explanation: Option B names the topic (a class garden), gives a clear opinion (our class should start one), and previews three reasons (teaches science, gives healthy snacks, and lets us work together), meeting all parts of the standard.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.1.B at easy difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.1.B at hard difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question: Read the opinion: "Our class should visit the science museum." Which sentence gives the best reason that supports this opinion?

answer_options.A: At the museum, we can see real sea turtles and how they swim, which will help us learn about science.
answer_options.B: The museum building is very tall and has many stairs.
answer_options.C: I like museums more than the park.
answer_options.D: The trip will take thirty minutes by bus.

answer_explanation: Option A explains a clear learning benefit—seeing real sea turtles—so it directly supports the opinion. The other options mention details about the museum that are not reasons for the visit or are only loosely connected.
subject: ELA

question: Which word best completes the sentence to connect the opinion to the reason? "I think riding a bike is the best way to get to school ______ it helps me stay active and have fun."

answer_options.A: and

answer_explanation: The word "because" is a linking word that clearly shows the reason for the opinion, explaining why riding a bike is considered the best way.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.1.C at hard difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question:
Which word best completes the sentence to connect the opinion with its reason?

"I think our class should plant a garden ______ the project will teach us about science and nature."

answer_options.A: however

answer_explanation: "Because" clearly introduces the reason (the project will teach science and nature) that supports the opinion (the class should plant a garden). The other choices do not correctly show this cause-and-effect link: "however" signals contrast, "for example" introduces an illustration, and "therefore" shows a result rather than a supporting reason.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.1.D at easy difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question:
Read the opinion paragraph below. Which sentence would be the STRONGEST concluding statement to finish the paragraph and give readers a clear sense of closure?

"I think our class should start a "No-Drip Day" where we turn off taps tightly after using them. A dripping faucet can waste gallons of water in one day, and saving water will also save our class money on the utility bill. Some students worry it sounds too hard, but if we all check every sink at the same time, it can be quick and fun. ________"

answer_options.A: Therefore, beginning a "No-Drip Day" will conserve water, save money, and teach us all to care for our planet.
answer_options.B: Turning off taps tightly can take only a second, and we have many sinks in our school.
answer_options.C: Actually, our class might also start a recycling program that separates paper and plastic for the custodians.
answer_options.D: Water is precious, so every drop we save helps the Earth stay healthy and green.

answer_explanation: A strong conclusion restates the opinion (start a No-Drip Day) and wraps up the two main reasons (save water and money), ending with a positive note that reinforces the call to action. Options B and D mention details from the paragraph without restating the opinion, and option C brings up a new idea (a recycling program) that begins a new piece rather than closing the current one.
subject: ELA

question:
Read the opinion paragraph below.

"Our school should start a garden club. Gardening teaches students how plants grow and helps us understand science in a fun way. Taking care of a garden also shows us how to work together and take care of the earth. When we grow our own vegetables, we learn that hard work can make something beautiful and tasty."

Which sentence would be the BEST way to conclude this paragraph?

answer_options.A: That's why a garden club would make our school a greener and wiser place to learn.
answer_options.B: Some students might prefer playing sports after class instead of gardening.
answer_options.C: Weeding the garden can be tricky, but the vegetables are worth the effort.
answer_options.D: The science teacher thinks gardening involves too much digging.

answer_explanation: A strong conclusion restates the main opinion and ties together the reasons without adding new information. Option A summarizes the benefits and clearly restates the idea that starting a garden club would help students, making it the most effective concluding statement.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.10 at easy difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question:
Mr. Carter posts four writing tasks for the week:
1) A science report about frogs for the class newsletter—use the library book, draft, revise, and edit before Friday.
2) A thank-you note to the crossing guard—write it the same day after school picks up.
3) A weather poem for art show viewers—finish it in one sitting.
4) A math reflection explaining how to solve 47 + 28 for a second-grader—due in two days.

Which student plan BEST shows writing routinely over both extended and shorter time frames for different purposes and audiences?

answer_options.A: Spend Monday–Thursday researching, drafting, revising, and editing the science report; write the thank-you note after school on Wednesday; compose the weather poem in one sitting on Friday; and draft the math reflection in one sitting, reread it once, and make changes before turning it in.
answer_options.B: Spend three full days revising the weather poem and the thank-you note but skip the science report and math reflection because they take too long.
answer_options.C: Write all four pieces in one morning so each piece gets the same amount of time, then turn them in without rereading or revising anything.
answer_options.D: Spend five days revising the science report and the math reflection; keep rewriting them even though they are already due, and do not write the note or the poem at all.

answer_explanation: Option A includes one extended task (the science report with research, drafting, revising, and editing over several days) and three shorter pieces (thank-you note, poem, math reflection) completed in a single sitting or within two days. It also addresses varied audiences and purposes, meeting every part of the standard.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.10 at medium difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question: Which sentence is the best way to start an informational paragraph about making a peanut butter and jelly sandwich?

answer_options.A: To make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, you need two slices of bread, peanut butter, and jelly.
answer_options.B: I like peanut butter and jelly sandwiches best.
answer_options.C: Peanut butter comes from peanuts inside pods.
answer_options.D: First, spread the jelly on one slice of bread.

answer_explanation: Option A introduces the topic (how to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich) and groups the main steps and ingredients together in one sentence, guiding what the paragraph will explain.
subject: ELA

question:
A student is writing an informational report about the water cycle. The student has these notes:
• The sun warms water in oceans and lakes.
• Water vapor rises into the air.
• Cool clouds form when water vapor condenses.
• Rain or snow falls to the ground.
• Plants give off water vapor through their leaves.
• Groundwater flows into rivers and back to the ocean.

Which plan BEST follows the rule: "Introduce a topic and group related information together"?

answer_options.A: Begin with: "Water moves in amazing ways." Then write one long paragraph mixing all the notes in the order they appear, without headings or categories.
answer_options.B: Begin with: "The water cycle is the journey of water around Earth." Group information into (1) "Water Moving Up" (sun warms water, vapor rises, plants give off vapor) and (2) "Water Falling Back" (condensation, rain/snow, groundwater to rivers).
answer_options.C: Begin with: "First, the sun heats water in lakes." Then list each note as a numbered step in the order water moves, but do not group related ideas (e.g., put plants in a separate list).
answer_options.D: Begin with: "The water cycle has four parts." Group the notes under two headings: "Evaporation" (sun warms water, vapor rises) and "Condensation" (clouds form, plants give off vapor, rain/snow falls, groundwater flows).

answer_explanation: Option B clearly introduces the topic and organizes the facts into two meaningful sections—"Water Moving Up" and "Water Falling Back"—so related information stays together. The other plans either mix details from different stages or leave important facts ungrouped.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.2.A at medium difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.2.B at easy difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question:
A student wrote this topic sentence for an informative paragraph:

"Volcanoes are powerful natural features."

Which sentence best develops the topic with facts, definitions, and details?

answer_options.A: Volcanoes are mountains that erupt hot lava and ash, and the molten rock called magma rises from deep inside Earth due to pressure buildup.
answer_options.B: Volcanoes are the most interesting natural features on Earth, and everyone should learn about them.
answer_options.C: Volcanoes erupt, and when they do, they can be dangerous.
answer_options.D: Volcanoes are natural features that can erupt, and eruptions can cause damage.

answer_explanation: Option A adds a clear definition of volcanoes and magma, a factual statement about pressure buildup, and a vivid detail about molten rock rising from Earth’s interior, fully developing the topic. The other options leave out at least one required element (a definition, a fact, or a specific detail).
subject: ELA

question: Which sentence best develops the topic "Deserts" with facts, definitions, and details?

answer_options.A: Deserts are the worst places to live because they are too hot and dry.
answer_options.B: Deserts are arid places that receive less than ten inches of rain each year, so many plants there, like cacti, have thick stems to store water.
answer_options.C: Deserts can be interesting if you want to see sand dunes and ride a camel.
answer_options.D: I read a book about deserts last week and thought it was really long.

answer_explanation: Option B provides a clear definition of deserts as places that receive less than ten inches of rain per year and adds a specific factual detail about the adaptations of desert plants, fully developing the topic. The other options give opinions or vague statements without clear facts or definitions.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.2.C at easy difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.2.C at hard difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question:
Which linking word best completes the sentence to connect the ideas?

"Penguins can swim fast in the icy ocean. _____, they have thick feathers that keep them warm in the cold water."

answer_options.A: But

answer_explanation: The word "Also" adds another related fact about penguins (their thick feathers) to the first fact (their swimming speed). The other choices show contrast, cause, or result, which do not fit the context of adding a similar detail.
subject: ELA

question: Read the paragraph: "Penguins are flightless birds that live in cold ocean waters. Their black and white feathers keep them warm and help them blend in while swimming. Penguins use their flippers to dive deep for fish, and they take care of their young in large groups." Which sentence would be the best concluding statement for this paragraph?

answer_options.A: Some penguins can dive more than 500 feet underwater.
answer_options.B: Because of these traits, penguins are well-suited for life in the ocean.
answer_options.C: Adelie penguins travel a long way to find food.
answer_options.D: The yellow oil that penguins have in their feathers keeps them dry.

answer_explanation: Option B restates the main idea by summarizing penguins’ key characteristics and provides closure without adding new details, which is the purpose of a concluding statement. The other options introduce new facts that would belong in the body of the paragraph.
subject: ELA

question: Which choice best demonstrates the skill described in W.3.2.D at hard difficulty?

answer_options.A: The correct choice that matches the standard.

answer_explanation: Option A is correct because it matches the skill described in the standard.
subject: ELA

question:
Read the paragraph below.

"Bats are the only mammals that can truly fly. Their wings are made of thin skin stretched across long finger bones, which helps them twist and turn sharply in the air. Bats also use echolocation to find insects in the dark. Because many bats eat mosquitoes and crop-eating moths, they help people in surprising ways."

Which sentence would be the BEST concluding statement for this paragraph?

answer_options.A: In conclusion, bats have remarkable flying and hunting skills that make them valuable helpers to humans.
answer_options.B: Some bats roost in caves, while others roost in trees.
answer_options.C: Bats are related to mice and dogs.
answer_options.D: To learn more about bats, visit a science museum near you.

answer_explanation: Option A wraps up the main ideas—bats’ special abilities and their importance to people—and leaves the reader with a clear final thought about bats. The other options introduce new facts (A) or shift to a different topic (B and D), so they do not serve as effective conclusions.
subject: ELA

question: Which sentence best begins a story by introducing the narrator and the situation?

answer_options.A: The city bus rumbled down the street, flashing bright lights in the evening rain.
answer_options.B: I'm Leah, and I'm about to ride the city bus all by myself for the very first time.
answer_options.C: Her brother's backpack was forgotten on the kitchen table, but he had already left for school.
answer_options.D: With a deep breath, the bird finally spread its wings and fluttered into the wind.

answer_explanation: Sentence B names the narrator (Leah) and explains what is about to happen (her first time riding the city bus alone), setting up the story clearly.
subject: ELA

question: Which sentence uses both dialogue and a description of action to show how a character feels?

answer_options.A: Mia hugged her knees and whispered, "I wish Grandma could come to the party," her eyes filling with tears.
answer_options.B: Mia wanted Grandma to come to the party.
answer_options.D: Mia wiped the cookies off the floor.

answer_explanation: Option A includes dialogue (Mia’s spoken words inside quotation marks) and an action (hugging her knees) that together show Mia’s sadness, meeting the standard’s requirement to use dialogue and descriptions of actions to develop events.
subject: ELA

question:
Read the draft sentence:

"Lena realized she was lost in the park after dark."

Which revision BEST develops the moment by using BOTH dialogue and descriptions of actions, thoughts, and feelings to show Lena’s response?

answer_options.A: Lena whispered, "Mom? I can’t find the playground," as tears pricked her eyes. She patted her coat pockets for the tenth time, wondering what time her mom would notice, and shivered, though the cold coins in her hand felt safer than the dark.
answer_options.B: Lena patted her coat pockets and whispered that she could not find the playground, growing nervous in the dim light.
answer_options.C: "I can’t find the playground," Lena whispered in the dim light, her voice shaking slightly.
answer_options.D: Lena patted her coat pockets, blinking at the pale streetlights as tears pricked her eyes.

answer_explanation: Choice A includes dialogue ("Mom? I can’t find the playground," Lena whispered) and detailed descriptions of Lena’s actions (patting her coat pockets, blinking at streetlights), thoughts (wondering what time her mom would notice), and feelings (growing nervous; cold coins pressed against her palm). These narrative techniques fully develop the event and her response, meeting the standard.
subject: ELA

question:
Read the paragraph.

Last Saturday, Maya and her brother helped their mom bake chocolate chip cookies. They measured the flour, cracked the eggs, and stirred the batter until it was smooth. When the cookies came out of the oven, the whole kitchen smelled sweet.

Which sentence would BEST complete the paragraph and provide a sense of closure?

answer_options.A: Maya and her brother grinned as they carried the cookies to the table and took their first warm bites.
answer_options.B: They almost spilled the sugar when the dog ran by.
answer_options.C: The recipe called for two cups of flour and a half-cup of sugar.
answer_options.D: Mom said they could bake another batch if they found more eggs.

answer_explanation: Option A shows the family enjoying the result of their work and signals that the event is finished, giving the story a clear ending. The other options either introduce a new problem, add an unrelated detail, or leave the action unfinished.
subject: ELA

question: Your teacher asks you to write a short set of instructions for planting a seed. Which sentence would be MOST appropriate to include in your writing?

answer_options.A: Plants are cool because they come in many colors and shapes.
answer_options.B: Next, sprinkle a thin layer of soil over the seed so it stays covered but not buried too deep.
answer_options.C: I think seeds should be called the best part of a plant because they grow into food.
answer_options.D: Seeds need water every day, and that is all you have to know about them.

answer_explanation: Option B gives a clear, ordered step that directly matches the task (planting a seed) and uses instruction-style language with a sequence word ("Next"). The other choices are opinions, facts, or loosely related statements that do not fit the purpose of explaining how to do something.
subject: ELA

question:
Jordan wrote this first draft for a story:

"We went to the fair. First we ate popcorn and rode the Ferris wheel. Then we played ring toss and won a prize it was a small stuffed bear. Next we rode the roller coaster it went click-clack-click really fast. Last we had cotton candy and went home.

A classmate says, “I like it, but I wish I could picture the rides better and feel the excitement.”
The teacher adds, “Your ideas run together, and you missed some commas and periods. Plan a quick outline, revise to combine sentences and add vivid details, and edit the conventions.”

Which set of actions best shows Jordan developing and strengthening his writing by planning, revising, and editing with guidance?

answer_options.A: Make a short outline (introduction, Ferris wheel and ring toss, roller coaster, conclusion), rewrite the draft to combine the roller-coaster sentences and add exciting describing words like "hair-whirling" and "loud," and then edit by adding missing commas and periods where the sentences still need them.
answer_options.B: Add several exciting words such as "super" and "awesome" to almost every sentence, but keep the run-on sentences exactly the way they are and do not change any punctuation.
answer_options.C: Correct only the punctuation errors (adding commas and periods) and keep almost every other sentence the same, so the rides are still hard to picture and the excitement is still low.
answer_options.D: Plan a completely different story about going to the zoo instead of using the feedback to improve the fair paragraph.

answer_explanation: Option A includes all three parts needed: making a quick outline (planning), revising by combining sentences and adding vivid, sensory details about the rides, and editing to fix the run-on sentences and correct comma and period placement. The other choices leave out one or more of these steps or ignore the feedback.
subject: ELA

question:
A classmate writes this draft:

"Yesterday I went to the park. We played and then we ate ice cream. Then we went home."

Which choice shows a way to DEVELOP AND STRENGTHEN THIS WRITING by planning, revising, and editing?

answer_options.A: Correct only the spelling mistakes and leave the sentences the same.
answer_options.B: Decide on a main idea (for example, how the park visit felt), add a few vivid details, and then check and fix capitals, periods, and commas.
answer_options.C: Rewrite the paragraph using bigger fonts and brighter colors without changing any words.
answer_options.D: Ask a friend to write the paragraph completely over so it looks neater without making any other changes.

answer_explanation: Option B adds a clear plan (a main idea and more details), revises the sentences to make the story stronger, and fixes small errors like adding missing capitals and punctuation, which is exactly what the standard means by planning, revising, and editing with help.
subject: ELA

question: Which action shows a third-grader using technology to produce and publish writing with help from an adult?

answer_options.A: Handwrite a poem in a notebook and keep it on the shelf
answer_options.B: Type a poem on a computer and print it to put in a desk
answer_options.C: Type a poem on a computer, with a teacher’s help, and post it on the class blog
answer_options.D: Draw a picture of a mountain and show it to the class without using a computer

answer_explanation: In option C, the student types the poem (uses technology to produce writing), shares it online (publishes), and does both with adult guidance, meeting every part of the standard.
subject: ELA

question: Which scenario best shows a third-grader meeting the standard by using technology to produce and publish writing with adult guidance and interacting with classmates along the way?

answer_options.A: Ella types a report on the classroom computer, shares the file with her teacher for comments, and then posts the finished report on the class blog where classmates can leave questions in the comments.
answer_options.B: Jaden handwrites a poem, gives it to his teacher who prints copies for the parents’ night, but Jaden never shows the poem to anyone else.
answer_options.C: Sofia records herself reading a story aloud on her tablet and only plays it for her little brother at home.
answer_options.D: Mateo types an essay on the classroom computer but closes the document without saving or sharing it with anyone.

answer_explanation: Option A includes keyboarding to create writing, publishing the piece online with teacher guidance, and inviting classmates to interact by leaving comments—fulfilling every part of the standard.
subject: ELA

question: Mr. Cruz says, “Use technology to write your story, publish it so classmates can read it, and work together online. I’ll help you along the way.” Which plan shows a third-grader following ALL parts of his directions?

answer_options.A: Ethan handwrites a story, scans the page, and saves the file without sharing it with anyone.
answer_options.B: Ivy types a poem on a computer, prints it, and hands the paper only to the teacher.
answer_options.C: Jamal creates a slideshow on his tablet, but he does not show or share it with the class.
answer_options.D: Maya opens a shared Google Doc, types her story, asks the teacher to check the links, and then adds classmates’ comments as a reply at the end.

answer_explanation: In option D, Maya types her story (producing with technology), posts it on a class website (publishing), responds to classmates’ comments (interacting and collaborating), and gets help from her teacher (guidance). Each other choice leaves out at least one required part.
subject: ELA

question: Which activity shows a short research project that builds knowledge about a topic?

answer_options.A: Writing a made-up story about a superhero without checking any sources
answer_options.B: Reading one book about butterflies and writing a note that says "Butterflies go through four life stages"
answer_options.C: Drawing a picture of a castle from your imagination and hanging it on the wall
answer_options.D: Asking a friend what they remember about turtles and stopping there

answer_explanation: A short research project requires gathering information from a reliable source (like a book) and recording a fact about the topic. Option B includes both steps, so it builds knowledge through research.
subject: ELA

question:
Read the notes Maya wrote for her report about birds:

1. "The park guide said eagles build huge nests in tall trees (print source)."
2. "I watched a documentary and wrote: 'Hawks fly very high in the sky' (digital source)."
3. "From my own experience, I know robins have bright red breasts."

Which note shows Maya taking brief notes from BOTH a print source and a digital source?

answer_options.A: Note 1 and Note 2

answer_explanation: Note 1 is from a print source (park guide), and Note 2 is from a digital source (documentary). Together they show information gathered from both types of sources, which matches the standard.
